title-group.article-title: Optimization of microwave vacuum drying of lotus (Nelumbo nucifera Gaertn.) seeds by response surface methodology

article-meta.aff: College of Food Science, Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Baodong Zheng, College of Food Science, Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University, Fuzhou, Fujian 350002, PR China. Email: zbdfst@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Drying is the main process used to treat lotus seeds for storage. In this study, response surface methodology was used to optimize processing methods for microwave vacuum (MWV) drying of lotus seeds and to create a desirable product. A central composite design with three important factors: microwave output power (2.0–4.0 kW), vacuum degree (−0.070 to −0.090 MPa) and on/off ratio (68/52 s to 99/21 s) was used to study the response variables of drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index. The optimum conditions for MWV drying of lotus seeds were determined to obtain a minimal drying time, minimal shrinkage ratio, maximum rehydration ratio and maximum whiteness index. The optimum drying conditions were found to be: microwave output power 3.2 kW, vacuum degree −0.083 MPa and on/off ratio 94/26 s. Under these optimal conditions, drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index were found to be 10 min, 37.66%, 157.1% and 68.83, respectively.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Lotus (Nelumbo nucifera Gaertn.) is widely grown and extensively cultivated in India, Japan and China (Bhat and Sridhar, 2008). In China, the largest area of cultivation is in the region from the middle of the Yangtze River and downstream (Guo, 2009). Lotus, a perennial aquatic plant, is well known as an ornamental, a dietary staple and is widely used medicinally in Eastern Asia, particularly in China (Kredy et al., 2010). The seeds of N. nucifera, called lianzi in traditional Chinese medicine, have a sweet and neutral flavor, and are medicinally associated with the spleen, kidney and heart meridians. They are taken to detoxify the spleen, reinforce the kidneys and nourish the blood. Lotus seeds have astringent properties (Yen et al., 2005), and are consumed to help relieve the symptoms of diarrhea and improve children’s appetites (Liu et al., 2004). The Chinese Pharmacopoeia (PCCn, 2005) records lotus seed as a traditional Chinese drug.

Several preservation methods have been used to extend the shelf-life of lotus seeds, such as canning, freezing and drying. Drying suppresses the activities of the microorganisms by removing moisture and inhibiting the activity of enzymes in lotus seeds which extends the shelf-life (Devece et al., 1999). Traditionally, during the processing of the seeds for storage and sale, drying lotus seeds is the best known method to reduce production costs and to increase productivity.

Hot air drying is commonly used to dry fruits and vegetables. However, hot air drying may cause a serious loss of quality in the taste, color, flavor, texture and nutritional content of the product. In hot air drying, the high temperatures and long drying times required to remove water from the fruit result in a decline in fruit density and water absorption capacity. Solutes are shifted from the inside of the dried material to the surface (Alibas, 2010; Maskan, 2000). Low thermal conductivity of food materials in hot-air drying results in limited heat transfer to the interior of the food (Feng and Tang, 1998). The use of microwaves for drying food prevents significant quality loss and improves drying efficiency. This has resulted in an increasing use of microwaves in food drying and reflects the desire to eliminate the disadvantages of hot air drying. However, microwave drying has the disadvantage of producing a non-homogenous heat distribution of heat, creating problems related to non-uniform heating (Abe and Afzal, 1997).

Microwave vacuum (MWV) drying is a novel, alternative and efficient method of food drying. It combines the advantages of both microwave and vacuum drying with faster mass transfer and lower temperatures (25–50 °C). MWV uses a more uniform and energy efficient drying method when compared to hot-air and microwave-drying methods (Argyropoulos et al., 2011; Contreras et al., 2005). During MWV drying, microwave energy is absorbed by water throughout the material being dried (Figiel, 2010). This significantly increases the vapor pressure in the center of the material, allowing a rapid transfer of moisture to the surrounding vacuum while preventing structural collapse (Lin et al., 1998). A puffing phenomenon accompanies the rapid dehydration produced by MWV (Sham et al., 2001). This produces a porous structure in food and facilitates production of a crispy and delicate texture (Sham et al., 2001). It also limits shrinkage while improving rehydration characteristics (Giri and Prasad, 2007a). Moreover, the absence of air during MWV drying may inhibit oxidation (Lin et al., 1998), while helping preserve color (Bondaruk et al., 2007; Yongsawatdigul and Gunasekaran, 1996). As described above, MWV drying has good potential for improving product quality. Some fruits and vegetables, such as carrots (Cui et al., 2004; Lin et al., 1998), garlic (Cui et al., 2003; Figiel, 2009), mushrooms (Giri and Prasad, 2007a, b) and potatoes (Bondaruk et al., 2007; Song et al., 2009b), have been successfully dried using MWV drying techniques. No scientific research has reported on the use of MWV drying for lotus seeds.

This study had two objectives. The first was to investigate the effect of three microwave and vacuum settings on four aspects of drying. The three settings are microwave power output, the degree of vacuum and on/off ratio. The four aspects of drying were drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and product color during MWV drying of lotus seeds. The second objective was to determine optimum conditions and processes for MWV drying of lotus seeds using response surface methodology (RSM).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Mature lotus seeds, with light-purple fruit coat, were harvested in Jianning County, Fujian Province, China. Then, the fruit coat, seed coat, spire and embryo root or Plumula nelumbinis were removed. The lotus seeds were stored at a temperature of 4 ± 0.5 °C until the start of the drying process. The initial moisture content was 1.08 ± 0.02 g/g, d.b. All samples used for drying were taken from a single batch of seed.

sec.title: Hot air drying
sec.p: The samples were hot air dried at an air temperature of 60 and 70 °C in an electric thermal dryer (Type-101-3, Shanghai Ruda Experimental Apparatus Co., Ltd., China) with an air flow velocity of 1.0 ± 0.03 m/s. Samples were spread in a single layer on the tray. The drying process continued until the moisture content of lotus seed samples reached 0.1 g/g, d.b.

sec.title: MWV drying
sec.p:
The multifunctional and programmable MWV dryer had a maximum nominal power of 4.2 kW and an operating frequency of 2450 MHz. We designed this drying system which was manufactured by Guangzhou Kailing Industrial Microwave Equipment Ltd., (Guangzhou, Guangdong, China). Figure 1 presents a schematic diagram of the equipment (Song et al., 2009a). The power could be adjusted between 0 and 4 kW. The 500 × 500 × 500 mm3 cubic microwave cavity had a maximum vacuum degree is −0.095 MPa. Six plates in the oven rotate at 1 rpm during operation. Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of WMV dryer: 1, WMV dryer box; 2, microwave generator; 3, microwave parafeed entrance; 4, vacuum drying room; 5, vacuum pipe; 6, support plate; 7, sample holder; 8, vacuum pump; 9, drive system; 10, electric motor.

The samples were spread in thin layers on dishes inside the microwave. The microwave power, vacuum degree and on/off ratio were set to the desired settings, so drying was performed at a preset power and time schedule. Moisture loss was recorded during drying by removing and weighing each dish on a digital balance (PL202-S100, Mettler Toledo Instruments (Shanghai) Co. Ltd., Shanghai, China) with 0.01 g precision. Drying process continued until the moisture content of lotus seed samples reached 0.1 g/g, d.b. (see calculation methods below). The dried samples were cooled to the ambient air temperature and then tested for moisture content, shrinkage, rehydration and color.

sec.title: Moisture content
sec.p: The moisture content was measured by the oven method (GB/T8858-88, National Standard of China). Lotus seed samples were placed in pre-dried aluminum dishes in an oven at 105 °C and dried to a constant weight. The samples were then moved to a desiccator for cooling, and then weighed using a balance sensitive to 0.01 g. Moisture content was calculated as (1)Xt=mt-m0m0 where Xt is the moisture content at t on dry basis (g/g, d.b.), t the drying time in minutes, mt the weight of material before drying t, m0 the dry weight of the material.

sec.title: Shrinkage
sec.p: Shrinkage, a result of dehydration, was used to evaluate volumeric changes of dried material. The shrinkage ratio of dried lotus seeds was calculated as (2)Shrinkage ratio(%)=V0-VV0×100 where V0 and V are the volume (cm3) of the original and dried materials, respectively.

The volume of samples were determined using the bead volumetric displacement method described by Cui et al. (2008). Glass beads (0.1 mm, USA Scientific Inc., Orlando, USA) were used as a replacement medium. The volume measurements were carried out in triplicate.

sec.title: Rehydration
sec.p: The rehydration ratio experiment used methods similar to those of Artnaseaw et al. (2010), with a little modification. Dried samples were immersed in hot water at 60 °C for 30 min. At 10 min intervals, the samples were drained over a mesh for 30 s and quickly and gently blotted with the paper towels 4 ± 5 times and then reweighed. The rehydration capacity, described as percentage water gain, was calculated from the sample weight difference before and after rehydration as (3)Rehydration ratio(%)=WtW0×100 where Wt is the weight of material (g) after rehydration and W0 the weight of material (g) before rehydration.

sec.title: Color
sec.p: The color of the dried lotus seeds was measured using a Chroma Meter (Chroma Meter WSC-S, Shanghai Precision and Scientific Instrument Co., Shanghai, China). The colorimeter was calibrated using a standard white reflector plate (X = 73.06, Y = 77.12 and Z = 80.10). The color parameters were recorded in CIE-lab scale as L*, a* and b*, where L* is the luminance or lightness component, and parameters a* (from green to red) and b* (from blue to yellow) are the two chromatic components. Color changes were measured using the following whiteness index (Oms-Oliu et al., 2008). (4)Whiteness index=100-(100-L*)2+(a*)2+(b*)2

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: The structure of the dried lotus seeds was examined using a scanning electron microscope (JEOL JSM-5310LV; JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). A thin slice about 1 mm thick was cut from the dried samples, fixed on the SEM stub and covered by gold using a sputter coater (JEOL JEC-1200). All samples were examined under high vacuum conditions at 20.0 kV.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p:
RSM was used to investigate the effects of microwave output power, vacuum degree and on/off ratio on the drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index. Table 1 gives the coded and uncoded independent variables used in the RSM design. The levels of the independent parameters were based on preliminary experimental results. As Table 2 shows, the experimental design was based on the central composition design (CCD), including 23 factorial points, six axial points (α = 1.682) and nine replicates of the central point. A second-order polynomial equation was used to express the drying time (Y1), shrinkage ratio (Y2), rehydration ratio (Y3) and whiteness index (Y4) as a function of the independent variables as (5)Yk=β0+∑βixi+∑βiixi2+∑βijxixj where Yk is the predicted response, β0 the intercept term, βi the linear coefficient, βii the squared coefficient and βij the interaction coefficient. Table 1.
The levels of variables employed in this study for the construction of central composition design (CCD)

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All analyses were performed in triplicate. The experimental results obtained were expressed as mean ± SD. Statistical analysis was performed using SAS software (version 9.1, SAS Institute, Cary, NC, USA). Data were analyzed by analysis of variance (ANOVA) (p < 0.05) and the means separated by Duncan’s multiple range test.

sec.title: Model results for MWV drying of lotus seeds
sec.p: Lotus seeds were dried under different conditions based on the experimental runs indicated by the model. Table 2 gives the complete 23 numbers of the experimental design matrix and responses based on experimental runs and predicted values on drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index proposed by CCD. The ranges of observed drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index were 6.5–23 min, 36.96–53.67%, 145.9–155.4% and 54.6–70.6, respectively. The model predictions satisfactorily matched these experimental results. Based on these results, an empirical relationship between the responses and independent variables were attained for MWV drying of lotus seeds and expressed by the following second-order polynomial equations: (6)Y1=13.9340-3.6144x1-1.9470x2-2.2432x3 -1.8125x1x2+0.1875x1x3+0.1204x2x3 +0.1204x1x1-0.0564x2x2+0.1204x3x3 (7)Y2=39.0884-0.6761x1-2.9734x2-1.9828x3 -0.2150x1x2-0.2275x1x3-0.4450x2x3 +4.1940x1x1+2.1581x2x2+1.6509x3x3 (8)Y3=154.3662+2.2145x1-0.6047x2+1.7802x3 -0.1500x1x2+0.3500x1x3-0.4000x2x3 -1.5771x1x1-1.6655x2x2-1.4888x3x3 (9)Y4=68.2689+0.8477x1+1.6660x2+1.0364x3 +1.0538x1x2-1.1263x1x3+1.1988x2x3 -1.0769x1x1-3.6236x2x2-2.6551x3x3

In Equations (6)–(9), x1, x2 and x3 are the coded variables for microwave output power, vacuum degree and on/off ratio, respectively. Table 3 shows the ANOVA results of the established model for drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index. The mean squares were obtained by dividing the sum of squares of each of the two sources of variation, the model and the error (residual) variance, by the respective degrees of freedom (DF). The model F-value was calculated by dividing the model mean square by residual mean square (Al-Harahsheh et al., 2009). As can be seen, the model F-values for drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index were found to be 57.4431, 15.3826, 106.3712 and 16.3554, respectively. These values indicate that the quadratic models are significant. Moreover, the statistical analysis indicated the proposed regression model for drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index was adequate, possessing no significant lack of fit and with satisfactory values of the R2 (multiple correlation coefficient) for all the responses. Table 3 shows the R2 values for drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index. The closer the value of R2 is to unity, the better the empirical model fits the actual data (Wu et al., 2007). Table 3.

The regression coefficients of all the four models were obtained and tested for adequacy and fitness using the p-value in Table 4. The p-values are used as a tool to check the significance of each coefficient, which in turn may indicate the pattern of the interactions between the variables. The smaller the p-value, the more significant the corresponding coefficient is (Hou and Chen, 2008). From the model of drying time, all the linear terms (x1, x2 and x3) and the interaction terms (x1x2 and x1x3) were significant (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). For the shrinkage ratio of lotus seeds, the linear terms (x2 and x3) and all the quadratic terms (x1x1, x2x2 and x3x3) were significant (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). For the rehydration ratio of lotus seeds, all the linear terms (x1, x2 and x3), the interaction term (x2x3) and all the quadratic terms (x1x1, x2x2 and x3x3) were significant (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). For the whiteness index of lotus seeds, the linear term (x2) and all the quadratic terms (x1x1, x2x2 and x3x3) were significant (p < 0.01 or p < 0.05). Table 4.

sec.title: Response surface and contour plots for MWV drying of lotus seeds
sec.p: SAS (version 9.1) was used with the three-dimensional (3D) response surface and two-dimensional (2D) contour plots of the regression model, while keeping one variable at its central level and allowing the others to wary within the experimental range. SAS was used to assess the effects of process variables and their interactions on the drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index of lotus seeds.

The time required to decrease the moisture content of lotus seeds from the initial value (1.08 g/g, d.b.) to 0.01 g/g, d.b. depended on the drying conditions. Figures 2a and 2d give the interactive effect of microwave output power and vacuum degree on drying time of lotus seeds, while using a 0-level on/off ratio. Both higher microwave output power and vacuum degree led to shorter drying times. When one was low, the other had little effect on drying time of lotus seeds (Figures 2a and 2d). With the vacuum degree set at 0 level, microwave output power and on/off ratio both had a positive impact on decreasing of drying time (Figures 2b and 2e). In addition, increasing vacuum degree and on/off ratio resulted in the significant decrease of the drying time of lotus seeds, when microwave output power was fixed at the 0 level. There was a linear decrease in drying time with increasing vacuum degree and on/off ratio (Figures 2c and 2f). Figure 2.
Response surface plots (a–c) and contour plots (d–f) showing the effect of microwave output power (X1), vacuum degree (X2) and on/off ratio (X3) on the drying time of lotus seeds (Y1).

Drying can produce some undesirable changes of food appearance, such as shrinkage. Figures 3a and 3d depict the interactive effect of microwave output power and vacuum degree on shrinkage ratio of lotus seeds at the 0 level of on/off ratio. Figures 3d and 3e show higher microwave output power and vacuum degree led to the lower shrinkage ratios. The positive effect of microwave output power on shrinkage reduction has been observed during MWV drying garlic (Figiel, 2009) and beet roots (Figiel, 2010). Rapid microwave energy absorption, due to high microwave power, caused rapid evaporation of water, creating a flux of rapidly escaping vapor which helps in preventing shrinkage (Giri and Prasad, 2007a). As Figure 3d shows, the minimum shrinkage ratio can be achieved using a microwave output power of about 3 kW (0 level). Figures 3b and 3e show the interactive effects of microwave output power and on/off ratio on the shrinkage ratio, when vacuum degree was set at the 0 level. Figures 3c and 3f show the interactive obvious effects of vacuum degree and on/off ratio on the shrinkage ratio, when microwave output power was set at the 0 level. Figure 3.
Response surface plots (a–c) and contour plots (d–f) showing the effect of microwave output power (X1), vacuum degree (X2) and on/off ratio (X3) on the shrinkage ratio of lotus seeds (Y2).

Figure 4 shows the effects of three independent factors on the rehydration ratio. With the on/off ratio at 0, an increase in rehydration ratio was initially observed with the increasing of microwave output power and vacuum degree, but the trend reversed when vacuum degree surpassed the 0 level (Figures 4a and 4d). Figures 4b and 4e demonstrate the interaction of microwave output power and on/off ratio on the rehydration ratio of lotus seeds at a fixed vacuum degree (0 level). Those figures also show that the rehydration ratio could be improved by increasing microwave output power. The higher rehydration ratio at higher microwave output power can be attributed to development of greater internal stresses during drying at the higher power levels (Giri and Prasad, 2007a). Moreover, the puffing characteristics generated by MWV drying could be beneficial to the rehydration performance (Sham et al., 2001). Figures 4c and 4f show the mutual interaction of vacuum degree and on/off ratio at a microwave output power of 3 kW; the rehydration ratio increased with the increases in the on/off ratio. The effect of on/off ratio on the rehydration ratio was significant (Table 4). These results are not in agreement with work conducted by Changrue and Orsat (2009). Figure 4.
Response surface plots (a–c) and contour plots (d–f) showing the effect of microwave output power (X1), vacuum degree (X2) and on/off ratio (X3) on the rehydration ratio of lotus seeds (Y3).

Figure 5 shows the effects of MWV drying process parameters on the whiteness index. Figures 5a and 5d show the effect of microwave output power and vacuum degree on the whiteness index. While the whiteness index reached a maximum near the central level of microwave output power at a fixed vacuum degree, increase in vacuum degree at a fixed microwave output power led to an increase in the whiteness index. The effect of microwave output power and on/off ratio shown in Figures 5b and 5e for the whiteness index of lotus seeds, demonstrating that the whiteness index increased with the increase of microwave output power at a fixed on/off ratio or with the increase of on/off ratio at a fixed microwave output power. Figures 5c and 5f show the response surface plot at various vacuum degrees and on/off ratios. Figure 5.
Response surface plots (a–c) and contour plots (d–f) showing the effect of microwave output power (X1), vacuum degree (X2) and on/off ratio (X3) on the whiteness index of lotus seeds (Y4).

sec.title: Optimization of process parameters
sec.p:
The following criteria were used to determine the optimum conditions for MWV drying of lotus seeds: minimum drying time and shrinkage ratio, and maximum rehydration ratio and whiteness index. Second-order polynomial models obtained in this study were used to obtain the optimized drying parameters meeting the above criteria. The optimized conditions were 3.2 kW for microwave output power, −0.083 MPa for vacuum degree and 94/26 s for on/off ratio. These resulted in the maximum desirability in the dried seeds (0.866): the optimized combination of drying parameters, the predicted drying time, the shrinkage ratio, the rehydration ratio and the whiteness index were 9.5 min, 38.52%, 155.1% and 67.67, respectively (Table 5). Table 5.
Predicted and experimental values for the responses at optimum conditions
X1 (kW) X2 (MPa) X3 DT (min) SR (%) RR (%) WI Desirability
Predicated 3.2 −0.083 96/24 s 9.5 38.52 155.0 67.67 0.866
Experimental 3.2 −0.083 96/24 s 10 37.66 157.1 68.83 –
Notes: DT, drying time; SR, shrinkage ratio; RR, rehydration ratio; WI, whiteness index; Desirability, desirability function.

sec.title: Verification of results
sec.p: Using the optimized parameters obtained from RSM with the desirability function, three additional verification experiments were performed. The experimental optimal drying time, the shrinkage ratio, the rehydration ratio and the whiteness index were 10 min, 37.66%, 157.1% and 68.83, respectively (Table 5). The good agreement between the predicted and experimental results verified the validity of the model and demonstrated the existence of an optimal set of conditions for drying.

sec.title: Comparison of hot air and MWV drying
sec.p:
Effect of different drying methods and conditions on the structure of dried lotus seeds was observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Conventional hot air-dried samples (Figure 6a) had a much less open structure and fewer pores when compared to MWV-dried samples (Figure 6b), indicating severe tissue shrinkage and collapse during air drying. The lower levels of shrinkage in the MWV-dried samples may be due to the shorter drying time, lower drying temperature and some tissue expansion from internal water vapor (Giri and Prasad, 2007a). Figure 6c shows lotus seeds dried using hot air, clearly showing some fractures and burning on the skin surface. The samples dried using MWV had a good appearance, with a uniformly milky white color and glossy surface (Figure 6d). Figures 6e and 6f present hot air-dried lotus seeds after rehydration and MWV-dried lotus seeds after rehydration, respectively. This demonstrates MWV-dried samples have good reconstitution ability during rehydration, which may be a result of their high porosity when compared with those dried with hot air (Bondaruk et al., 2007). Figure 6.
(a) SEM of conventional hot air-dried lotus seeds; (b) SEM MWV-dried lotus seeds; (c) hot air-dried lotus seeds; (d) MWV-dried lotus seeds; (e) hot air-dried lotus seeds after rehydration; (f) MWV-dried lotus seeds after rehydration.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: RSM was used in this study to optimize the MWV drying process of lotus seeds. Results show that the second-order polynomial model adequately described and predicted the responses of drying time, shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index in MWV drying processes of lotus seeds within the experimental ranges. The independent parameters of microwave output power, vacuum degree and on/off ratio significantly affected the drying time and quality properties of lotus seeds. Optimal conditions for minimal drying time, minimal shrinkage ratio, maximum rehydration ratio and optimal whiteness index in MWV drying of lotus seeds were found. The optional microwave output power, vacuum degree and on/off ratio were found to be 3.2 kW, −0.083 MPa and 94/26 s, respectively. This resulted in an optimal drying time, the shrinkage ratio, rehydration ratio and whiteness index of 10 min, 37.66%, 157.1% and 68.83, respectively.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: The research was financially supported from projects that include China State ‘11th Five-Year Plan’ scientific and technological support scheme (2007BAD07B05); Special major science and technology in Fujian Province (2008N0007); Natural science fund in Fujian Province (2011J05123).
